chunks.zh: 已裸辞, 3 月份准备日本旅行, 有没有什么注意的
chunks.en: I've quit my job, and I'm preparing for a trip to Japan in March. Are there any things I should pay attention to?

chunks.zh:
裸辞结束沪漂了, 返乡前准备穷游一段时间

第一站日本(大阪 京都 东京), 一个人, 计划**7-10**天

老哥们有没有什么注意事项或者经验分享
比如: ***美食景点 / 摄影机位 / 人文风情:) / 购物推荐*** 什么的
chunks.en:
I've quit my job and finished drifting in Shanghai. Before going back home, I'm planning a backpacking trip for a while.

First stop: Japan (Osaka, Kyoto, Tokyo), solo traveler, plan for **7-10** days.

Brothers, do you have any precautions or experience to share?
For example: ***food attractions / photography spots / culture and customs :) / shopping recommendations*** or something like that

chunks.zh: https://spangle-measure-e08.notion.site/Japan-2025-7-8-172ade55c4768099b75bd6a5664828cd可以看下我的 notion ，2 月份刚去，吃喝玩乐买，包括新干线
chunks.en: https://spangle-measure-e08.notion.site/Japan-2025-7-8-172ade55c4768099b75bd6a5664828cd You can check out my Notion. I just went in February. It covers eating, drinking, entertainment, shopping, including the Shinkansen.

chunks.zh: @punching2012 #7 吃饭要预约的情况有，但你反过来想想，难道在日本工作生活的人天天吃饭都要预约嘛，也不现实。高端餐厅预约制，牛马套餐那还不是随便吃 doge 不会饿着的。#11 交流翻译软件基本就行了，你要注意的是准备开好漫游，或者买当地流量卡，或者租个 wifi 设备，尽量保证网别断。实在不行，中国人遍地都是，你对着空气喃喃自语，会随机刷新中国人 NPC 帮你的除了打卡地，多花些时间做做普通人做的事情，类似体验换个地方生活一天——正常去超市、坐地铁瞎溜达（ citywalk ）、普通餐厅/咖啡店/面包店/酒店/超市/公园逛逛，有些细节是跟国内完全不同的体验，还是很有趣的，不一定非得奔着完成什么 KPI 的目标刷打卡点。注意，酒店基本都是 2 点后才能入住；东京市区地铁等换乘比较复杂，提前下好地铁软件，熟悉下界面（ Google map 也很有用）有些交通票可以买通票/联程票，便宜很多，提前做好攻略。 （私货）瞎溜达比去打卡点挤人堆体验更好
chunks.en: @punching2012 #7 There are situations where you need to make reservations for meals, but think about it the other way around, do people who work and live in Japan make reservations for every meal? That's not realistic either. High-end restaurants require reservations, but you can still eat casual meals doge and won't go hungry. #11 Communication with translation software is basically enough. What you need to pay attention to is to prepare to enable roaming service, or buy a local SIM card, or rent a Wi-Fi device, in order to ensure that your network connection doesn't get cut off. If all else fails, Chinese people are everywhere. If you talk to the air, Chinese NPCs will randomly appear to help you. Besides the famous spots, spend more time doing what ordinary people do, like experiencing life in a different place for a day—go to the supermarket, take the subway and wander around (citywalk), visit ordinary restaurants/cafes/bakeries/hotels/supermarkets/parks, there are some details that are completely different from the experience in China, which are quite interesting. Don't necessarily aim to complete any KPI-like goals when visiting the famous spots. Note that hotels generally allow check-in after 2 p.m.; subways and other transfers in Tokyo city are more complicated, download subway software in advance and familiarize yourself with the interface (Google Map is also very useful). Some transportation tickets can be bought as a pass/through ticket, which is much cheaper, so make a plan in advance. (Personal tip) Wandering around aimlessly is a better experience than squeezing with the crowd at the famous spots.

chunks.zh: 一个朋友说，他在日本闯红灯的时候，会跟同行人说一句：lets go 斯密达。
chunks.en: A friend said that when he runs a red light in Japan, he will say to his companions: lets go Simida.

chunks.zh: 去年去的，一点点攻略，https://www.mengke.me/blog/202405/Travels_In_Japan
chunks.en: I went last year, a little bit of a travel guide, https://www.mengke.me/blog/202405/Travels_In_Japan

chunks.zh: 在日旅居过一年。食：低端御三家食其家、吉野家、松屋，都有点餐机，可选中文，人均 50 CNY 以下。中、高端餐厅看 Google Map 或 食べログ，注意日本人习惯默认评分是 3 星，Google Map 4 星+ 的店基本纯是游客向的，不推荐，容易遇到阴阳菜单。高端餐厅一般需要预约。店家不愿意服务非日语客户的一般发生在高档传统餐厅。支付：仅有少量小店是現金だけ，连锁店都可以刷卡，兼容性来说 VISA 最好，其次是 AMEX （专门办 JCB 没必要，在日 JCB 和 AMEX 有互认协议）。国内很多信用卡境外线下返点都蛮高的，比微信支付宝划算。行：iPhone 可开 suica 支持银联信用卡充值，有带着用 Android 的朋友一起的话，可以再开张 icoca 、passmo 之类的，切换着过闸机，游客使用没有任何区别。注意九州、冲绳等乡下地方很多需要现金购票。初次自由行，除非要坐新干线，否则不推荐买任何套票、一日券等，因为线路分 JR メトロ 私铁等优惠算法复杂，不严格依照规划行程走的话容易反亏。打车较贵，实在要打注意日本出租是由司机开关门的，可以滴滴 uber （比直接招手多 5-800 日元调度费）住：东京大阪什么时候都贵。其他地方酒店潮汐效应明显，周末和节假日房价 x2 ，x3 是常态。乡下如仙台 200 人民币可以住平日带温泉的酒店。姬路 600 可以私汤+一泊二食。游：日本的几乎所有商圈、热闹街区都是围绕车站兴建的。即便东京离开车站步行 10 分钟也秒变大农村。
chunks.en: I lived in Japan for a year. Food: Low-end three major restaurants, Sukiya, Yoshinoya, and Matsuya, all have ordering machines and Chinese options, with an average of less than 50 CNY per person. For mid-range and high-end restaurants, check Google Maps or Tabelog. Note that Japanese people usually default the rating to 3 stars. Shops with 4 stars+ on Google Maps are basically tourist-oriented and not recommended, as they may have different menus for tourists. High-end restaurants usually require reservations. Shops that are unwilling to serve non-Japanese-speaking customers usually occur in high-end traditional restaurants. Payment: Only a small number of small shops accept cash only. Chain stores can all be paid by card. In terms of compatibility, VISA is the best, followed by AMEX (it is unnecessary to apply for a JCB card specifically, as JCB and AMEX have a mutual recognition agreement in Japan). Many domestic credit cards have high cashback rates for offline spending abroad, which is more cost-effective than WeChat Pay and Alipay. Transportation: iPhones can open Suica and support UnionPay credit card top-ups. If you are traveling with friends who use Android phones, you can open an Icoca or Passmo card. There is no difference for tourists. Note that in rural areas such as Kyushu and Okinawa, you need to buy tickets with cash. For first-time independent travel, unless you need to take the Shinkansen, it is not recommended to buy any passes or one-day tickets, because the discounts for lines such as JR, Metro, and private railways are complex, and it is easy to lose money if you do not strictly follow the planned itinerary. Taxis are expensive. If you really want to take a taxi, pay attention that Japanese taxis are driven by the driver who opens and closes the doors. You can use Didi or Uber (which is 500-800 yen more expensive than hailing a taxi). Accommodation: Tokyo and Osaka are always expensive. The hotel tidal effect is obvious in other places. Weekend and holiday room rates are x2, x3 is the norm. In the countryside, such as Sendai, you can stay in a hotel with a hot spring on weekdays for 200 RMB. Himeji 600 can have a private bath + one night and two meals. Sightseeing: Almost all shopping districts and bustling streets in Japan are built around train stations. Even in Tokyo, a 10-minute walk from the station can turn into a rural area.

chunks.zh: 1. 机票及机场出发	1. 建议选择飞猪，对比去哪儿，飞猪国际航班便宜大概三四百。（也可以对比其他平台）可以看看前后各一天的价格，有时候差别挺大。	2. 购买国际航班需要填写护照信息，所以提前需要办理护照。	3. 国际航班需要过边检，而且国内的国际航班必须在柜台值机，建议预留 3 小时左右提前到达机场办理值机。（国航可以在小程序进行预选座位，需要凤凰知音积分或者 50 元）	4. 边检会问些基本问题（去哪、电子签证、「是否工作“随便说就行 不详查”」、返程航班、酒店行程等）没问题三四分钟就能盖章放行。	5. 入境单可以填写电子版 Google 搜 Visit Japan Web ，或者<font size=4, color='yellow'>带只笔</font>在飞机上填写纸质的。（建议填写纸质的，我电子的不知道哪不合格被要求重填纸质）2. 酒店	1. 平台可以选择：飞猪、Booking 、Agoda 等平台，重点对比价格和评价，不要选择离车站特别近的，铁轨会很吵，根据自己要逛的地方选择距离车站一公里内的中心地点。	2. 选择酒店时选择实际入住人数，房费是按实际人数入住人数收费的；看好价格是否含税，如果不含部分酒店要在前台办理入住时缴纳消费税，看好是否提供 WiFi 。	3. 建议选择高档一些的酒店，前台沟通和服务相对高一些，沟通和入住体验会好很多。	4. 酒店除毛巾外其他的一次性日用品基本上都会在大堂放着，房间内不会预留。	5. 日本国内电压是 110v ，携带国内家电和电子产品时看好充电器的输入功率，手机之类的可以直充 不需要转接头，大功率的需要购买变压器。	6. 部分酒店的电视节目是收费的，最好看下房间内的入住引导单和电视提示信息，没必要就别看，不然退房时会被收费。	7. 酒店的手纸可以直接冲水，苏菲啥的有提供专门的袋子装。	8. 酒店基本的入住在 14 点之后，退房在 11 点之前，都提供行李寄存。3. 日本出行	1. iPhone 钱包可以办电子交通卡，用多少充多少。而且交通卡可以买东西，便利店和商场都可以用。	2. 日本地铁分特急、准特急、普通，速度不同，都是进出站个刷一次卡，特急需要额外付特急费，车站购买或者车上会有人找你确认 没有直接补就行；部分有轨电车全程一个价，上车不刷，下车刷卡；坐 JR 线（一般都是机场或者远途）和公交提前小红书搜一搜注意事项。	3. 推荐使用 Google Map ，换乘和车次等相关信息很详细，还可以预定餐厅。	4. 重点：人家不安检，机场都不用手持安检仪。	5. 买个带拉链的钱包，不然硬币没地装；出门背个包，垃圾是真的没多少地方扔。4. 吃饭	1. Google Map 可以搜餐厅，部分餐厅会显示预约等字样，这种需要提前预约的 不然不提供服务。（预约好像需要注册什么账号，太复杂没搞）	2. 结账时看下前台是不是有收钱的盘子，日本结账一般都是把现金放到盘子里面，付款方式一般是现金、刷卡、部分支持支付宝，微信很少。	3. 点餐的话指着对应的食物配合“this one”万能，常规英文都能听懂，不行再上翻译，千万不要在乎掉面儿。	4. 便利店 711 和全家都有自主结账机，东西给店员后，直接在机器投钱就行。大街上买水的机器一大堆 不用担心口渴。5. 游玩	1. 提前在地图查下路线以及营业时间。	2. 不是热门景区可以现场买票，热门景点最好提前买票，飞猪和 Booking 都有，Google Map 搜索对应景点也可以查看票务信息。	3. 寺庙有些内堂需要脱鞋进入，准备好舒适的鞋袜。	4. 日本寺庙和神社不要瞎拜，不知道里面供奉的什么玩意。6. 其他事项	1. 建议办理一个 visa 或者 master ，银联卡应用范围比较小。	2. 出门随身带着护照、现金和银行卡。	3. 日元兑换一个人建议兑换 5 万日元即可，两个人兑换十万以下够用了。	4. 提前买流量卡，日本也有免费的公共 WiFi ，到景区和机场、商场之类的可以打开 WiFi 搜索。
chunks.en: 1. Air tickets and airport departure 1. It is recommended to choose Fliggy (飞猪), compare it with Qunar (去哪儿). International flights on Fliggy are about 300-400 yuan cheaper. (You can also compare other platforms) You can check the prices of the day before and after, sometimes the difference is quite large. 2. When purchasing international flights, you need to fill in your passport information, so you need to apply for a passport in advance. 3. International flights require border inspection, and domestic international flights must check in at the counter. It is recommended to arrive at the airport 3 hours in advance to check in. (Air China can pre-select seats on the mini program, which requires PhoenixMiles miles or 50 yuan) 4. The border inspection will ask some basic questions (where to go, electronic visa, "whether to work "just say whatever you want, no detailed investigation", return flight, hotel itinerary, etc.) You can pass the inspection in three or four minutes. 5. The entry form can be filled electronically, search Visit Japan Web on Google, or <font size=4, color='yellow'>bring a pen</font> and fill it out on the plane. (It is recommended to fill in the paper form, because I don't know where my electronic form failed, so I was asked to refill the paper one) 2. Hotel 1. Platforms to choose from: Fliggy, Booking, Agoda and other platforms. Focus on comparing prices and reviews. Don't choose hotels that are too close to the train station, the tracks will be noisy. Choose a central location within one kilometer of the train station based on where you want to visit. 2. When choosing a hotel, select the actual number of guests. The room rate is charged according to the actual number of guests. Check whether the price includes tax. If it is not included, some hotels need to pay consumption tax at the front desk when checking in. Check whether WiFi is provided. 3. It is recommended to choose a more upscale hotel, as the communication and service at the front desk will be relatively higher, and the communication and check-in experience will be much better. 4. Except for towels, other disposable daily necessities are basically placed in the lobby, and will not be pre-arranged in the room. 5. The domestic voltage in Japan is 110v. When carrying domestic appliances and electronic products, pay attention to the input power of the charger. Mobile phones and other devices can be charged directly without an adapter. High-power devices need to buy a transformer. 6. Some hotel TV programs are charged. It is best to check the check-in guide in the room and the TV prompt information. Don't watch it if you don't need to, otherwise you will be charged when checking out. 7. The toilet paper in the hotel can be flushed directly, and there are special bags for sanitary napkins. 8. Basic check-in at the hotel is after 2 p.m., and check-out is before 11 a.m. Luggage storage is provided. 3. Travel in Japan 1. You can get an electronic transportation card in your iPhone wallet, and top it up as much as you use. Moreover, the transportation card can be used to buy things, and convenience stores and shopping malls can all be used. 2. Japanese subways are divided into express, semi-express, and ordinary. The speeds are different. You need to swipe your card when entering and exiting the station. The express trains require an extra express fee. You can buy it at the station or someone on the train will confirm it with you. You just need to pay directly. Some streetcars have a fixed price for the entire journey. You don't swipe your card when you get on, but swipe it when you get off. Please search for precautions on Xiaohongshu (小红书) in advance when taking the JR line (generally for airports or long distances) and buses. 3. It is recommended to use Google Map. The information about transfers and train times is very detailed, and you can also book restaurants. 4. Important point: they don't have security checks, not even at the airport. 5. Buy a wallet with a zipper, otherwise you won't have a place to put your coins. Carry a bag when you go out, there is really not much place to throw garbage. 4. Eating 1. You can search for restaurants on Google Map. Some restaurants will show words like reservation, which requires you to make a reservation in advance, otherwise they will not provide service. (It seems that you need to register an account to make a reservation, which is too complicated and I didn't figure it out) 2. When checking out, check if there is a tray for receiving money at the front desk. Japanese people usually put cash into the tray. Payment methods are generally cash, card, and some support Alipay, but WeChat is rare. 3. When ordering food, it is versatile to point to the corresponding food and say “this one”. Regular English can be understood. If not, then use a translation app. Don't care about losing face. 4. Convenience stores 711 and FamilyMart have self-checkout machines. After giving the items to the clerk, you can put the money directly into the machine. There are a lot of machines for buying water on the street, so you don't need to worry about being thirsty. 5. Sightseeing 1. Check the route and business hours on the map in advance. 2. You can buy tickets on the spot for non-popular scenic spots. It is best to buy tickets for popular scenic spots in advance. Fliggy and Booking all have them. You can also check the ticket information by searching for the corresponding scenic spot on Google Map. 3. Some temples require you to take off your shoes to enter the inner hall, so prepare comfortable shoes and socks. 4. Don't worship Japanese temples and shrines blindly. You don't know what is enshrined inside. 6. Other matters 1. It is recommended to apply for a Visa or Mastercard, as UnionPay cards are not widely used. 2. Carry your passport, cash, and bank card with you when you go out. 3. It is recommended that one person exchange 50,000 yen, and two people can exchange less than 100,000 yen. 4. Buy a data SIM card in advance. Japan also has free public WiFi. You can turn on WiFi and search when you go to scenic spots, airports, and shopping malls.

chunks.zh: @punching2012 #5 夜间大巴好评，一般直接到新宿站。
chunks.en: @punching2012 #5 Night buses are a good choice, they usually go directly to Shinjuku Station.

chunks.zh: 京都的话，各类小巷子什么的也很好逛很好拍。走走逛逛很休闲。拍二年坂三年坂清水寺附近这种热门景点，想出片，建议找晴天早上八点前去。人多拍出来就游客打卡照了。天气好了，鸭川沿岸可以走走，能感受到当地人的闲适。如果喜欢和咖啡吃甜点，京都有很多不错的小咖啡馆，走累了可以调一个顺眼的 walk in ，基本不踩雷。
chunks.en: If you go to Kyoto, all kinds of alleys are also great to walk around and take pictures. Walking around is very relaxing. To take good photos of popular attractions near Ninenzaka, Sannenzaka, and Kiyomizu-dera Temple, it is recommended to go before 8 a.m. on a sunny day. If there are too many people, it will only look like a tourist snapshot. If the weather is good, you can walk along the Kamogawa River and feel the leisure of the locals. If you like coffee and desserts, Kyoto has many good small cafes. You can choose a walk-in cafe that looks good when you are tired, and you won't go wrong.

chunks.zh: @punching2012 #11 好的, 交流困难吗, 我日语完全不会, 英语也没现实场景开口交流过====================准备几个常用的英语和日语单词就行，再下载一个翻译软件以防万一。毕竟你是花钱的人，他们态度会很好的。
chunks.en: @punching2012 #11 Okay, is it difficult to communicate? I don't know any Japanese at all, and I've never spoken English in a real-life situation. ==================== Just prepare a few commonly used English and Japanese words, and then download a translation software just in case. After all, you are the one paying, so they will have a good attitude.

chunks.zh: 京都的话去稻荷神社顺着台阶爬上去，有一处休息的地方，专门看日落的，看天际线。去年十月一我们去的那，大家爬上去一直坐在那个地方，看日落，看月亮，看星星，各国人大家就那么坐着，非常舒服。
chunks.en: If you go to Kyoto, go to Fushimi Inari Shrine and climb up the stairs. There is a resting place specifically for watching the sunset and the skyline. We went there last October, and everyone climbed up and sat there, watching the sunset, the moon, and the stars. People from all countries sat there together; it was very comfortable.

chunks.zh: @callmejoejoe 毒株国内外都差不多，没啥担心的
chunks.en: @callmejoejoe The virus strains are similar both at home and abroad, so there's nothing to worry about.

chunks.zh: 一个关于找美食的 tips错误：去找 xhs 上的店正确：Google Map 上高分店
chunks.en: A tip about finding food: Wrong: look for shops on Xiaohongshu (xhs). Right: High-rated shops on Google Map.

chunks.zh: 时差一小时, 小心误机
chunks.en: The time difference is one hour, be careful not to miss your flight.

chunks.zh: - 新干线和特急都要买急行券，然后两张一起过票检。除非预约，不然个人一般习惯 Suica 直进直出，所以更喜欢急行。不过新干线和特急的乘坐体验确实更棒。车也更漂亮- 除非碰到小概率事件，Google Map 导航是能告诉你 platform Number 的。所以坐电车可以直接 Google Map ，suica 进站，去对应 platform 上车即可。在小站碰到过两次临时换道（月台弃物，车站故障），如果不会日文，只能询问工作人员了。- 国际机场、大型车站这些地方都有会有中文的日方员工。但小地方，地铁站确实不一定会有。练习下英文吧。如果是大城市或者热门景点，其实很容易碰到中国人的。- 碰到过的大多数日本人都能说英文，甚至年纪很大的老司机口音还非常标准。- 吃饭要是网红点最好预约。有些地方没预约能等到晚上 22：00 后。但预约比较死，予約多少人，去也得多少人。普通店就无所谓。如果一人行，确实予約也会受限。- 日本鲜少有早餐店，酒店不包早餐的话就只能去便利店了。- 5000 円往上可免税，所以购物前记得带护照。- 准备个小硬币包吧，用现金的地方比较多，有的小店甚至只收现金- 拍他人的话，最好获得许可，这也是种礼貌- 各地风景都非常漂亮，个人更喜欢寺庙，神社，公园，日式庭院确实非常优美。我喜欢拍照顺便收集各种御朱印。- 环球，迪士尼我个人挺无感的。如果要去，像马里奥手表，哈里波特魔杖好像国内有租赁服务。- 个人更喜欢泡温泉，东京附近就是箱根了吧。之前也去过，是个爬山，泡温泉的好地方。虽然最近大 S……　那边可以乘坐小火车上山，沿途各站都有美術館。慢慢一站一站玩过去，晚上去泡温泉，非常不错。预祝旅行愉快
chunks.en: - You need to buy express tickets for both Shinkansen and limited express trains, and then pass through the ticket gate together. Unless you make a reservation, people generally like to use Suica for direct entry and exit, so they prefer express trains. However, the experience of riding the Shinkansen and limited express trains is indeed better. The trains are also more beautiful. - Unless a low-probability event occurs, Google Maps navigation can tell you the platform number. So you can directly use Google Maps for the train, enter the station with Suica, and get on the corresponding platform. I've encountered temporary track changes (items left on the platform, station malfunction) twice at small stations. If you don't know Japanese, you can only ask the staff. - There will be Japanese staff who can speak Chinese at international airports and large train stations. But in small places, there may not be one at the subway station. Practice your English. If you are in a big city or a popular tourist destination, it's actually easy to run into Chinese people. - Most Japanese people I've met can speak English, and even very old drivers have very standard accents. - It's best to make a reservation for popular restaurants. Some places may require you to wait until after 10:00 pm without a reservation. But reservations are quite inflexible. The number of people you reserve for must match the number of people who go. Ordinary shops don't matter. If you are traveling alone, reservations will indeed be limited. - There are very few breakfast shops in Japan. If your hotel doesn't include breakfast, you can only go to a convenience store. - You can get tax-free shopping for purchases over 5000 yen, so remember to bring your passport before shopping. - Prepare a small coin purse, as there are many places that use cash. Some small shops even only accept cash. - If you want to take pictures of others, it's best to get permission, which is also a courtesy. - The scenery in various places is very beautiful. I personally prefer temples, shrines, parks, and Japanese gardens, which are really beautiful. I like taking pictures and collecting various Goshuin stamps. - I'm not very interested in Universal Studios and Disney. If you want to go, services like renting Mario watches and Harry Potter wands seem to be available domestically. - I personally prefer hot springs, and Hakone is near Tokyo. I went there before, and it's a great place for climbing mountains and soaking in hot springs. Although recently Da S... You can take a small train up the mountain there, and there are art museums at each station along the way. Play slowly from station to station, and go to a hot spring at night, which is very nice. I wish you a pleasant trip.

chunks.zh: 京都大德寺 你值得拥有
chunks.en: Kyoto's Daitoku-ji Temple, you deserve to have it.

chunks.zh: 说三遍 硬币 硬币 硬币！ 硬币是真 TMD 多，我揣了两口袋的硬币回国，所以劝你做好花硬币的规划
chunks.en: Say it three times: Coins, coins, coins! There are really a lot of coins. I brought two pockets of coins back to my country, so I advise you to plan how to spend them.

chunks.zh: @chanChristin google maps 自己搜飞田新地 松岛新地 信太山新地去玩就可以了
chunks.en: @chanChristin You can search for Tobita Shinchi, Matsushima Shinchi, and Shinodayama Shinchi on Google Maps and go have fun.

chunks.zh: @TimePPT 京都最爱是鸭川
chunks.en: @TimePPT My favorite in Kyoto is the Kamogawa.

chunks.zh: 放平心态,谷歌评论如果哪家不接待外国人也不用去纠结.如果坐车的地铁有意外故障,离开前先去卖票口让他开个故障的证明,我那次地铁说电压问题取消,后换乘其他新干线坐飞机晚点了,在机场的地铁站要了条子折腾了好久给免费改签飞机了
chunks.en: Relax. If a place doesn't accept foreigners according to Google reviews, don't bother with it. If there is an unexpected fault on the subway you are riding, go to the ticket office before leaving and ask them to issue a proof of the fault. That time the subway was canceled due to voltage issues, and after transferring to another Shinkansen flight, I was late. After a long time of hassle, I obtained a free ticket to a different flight at the airport subway station.

chunks.zh: @icecream 巢鸭和大塚站出口附近都有很多粉红沙龙，你 googlemaps 搜索ピンクサロン就可以了，我 12 月去的时候探索了一下，大塚附近的店都拒绝外国人，巢鸭附近的还好。这个超级便宜，3000 元左右就可以发射（白天去的情况下），里面的服务自行谷歌，但是风俗娘整体年龄偏大，不过技术都很好传统的正规本番店东京只有吉原，Google 三之轮站出来，然后搜索「千束」，走一公里多就到了风俗店区，然后就自行探索吧，第一次玩我推荐 60 分，在 2.5-5 万，都有，我一般消费两万多的店，基本的服务也还可以了，但是风俗娘外形肯定不够顶，价格越高外貌越好，之前我朋友玩了个 9 万 120 分的，他说特别好看。一般在门口有人招呼的，百分之 80 外国人都可以消费，外国人料金+5000 ，如果你日语好可以商量一下不要钱，但是如果碰到说外国人不行的，就不要商量了，直接走，日本人比较讨厌这种不尊重规矩的。日语需要学一句这个，外人でも大丈夫？ Gai Jin Dei Mo Dai Jou bu? 盖金 dei 莫呆胶布？进店的时候问一下外国人接不接待，不然一切都等于 0 了。另外 googlemaps 的差评还是值得参考的，因为日本人玩完了会写评论我玩过的地方是这两个，供参考哈
chunks.en: @icecream There are many pink salons near the exits of Sugamo and Otsuka stations. You can search for ピンクサロン on Google Maps. I explored them in December. The shops near Otsuka refused foreigners, but the ones near Sugamo were okay. This is super cheap, you can experience it for about 3,000 yen (in the daytime). You can Google the services inside, but the overall age of the girls is relatively older, but the techniques are very good. The only traditional, legitimate bonban shop in Tokyo is Yoshiwara. Come out of the Google Sanno-rind station, then search for "Senryu", and walk a kilometer or so to the red-light district, and then explore on your own. For the first time, I recommend 60 minutes. The prices are between 25,000 and 50,000 yen. I usually spend more than 20,000 yen in a shop, and the basic service is still okay, but the appearance of the girls may not be the best. The higher the price, the better they look. My friend played a 120-minute session for 90,000 yen before, and he said it was particularly beautiful. Generally, someone will greet you at the door, and 80% of foreigners can spend money. Foreigner fee + 5,000 yen. If you are good at Japanese, you can negotiate not to pay this extra fee, but if the person says that foreigners are not allowed, don't negotiate, just walk away. Japanese people dislike those who don't respect the rules. You need to learn this sentence in Japanese, 外人でも大丈夫？ Gai Jin Dei Mo Dai Jou bu? (Gai Jin Dei Mo Dai Jou bu?) Ask at the entrance if they accept foreigners, otherwise everything is equal to zero. In addition, the negative reviews on Google Maps are still worth referring to, because Japanese people will write reviews after they are done. The two places I have played are for your reference.
